TITLE: Tech's biggest event starts this week. Here's what to expect
SUMMARY: CES, typically one of the year's biggest tech trade shows, is moving forward with plans to host an in-person component this week despite looming threats of the Omicron Covid-19 variant.

TITLE: India is investigating a fake website that offered Muslim women for sale
SUMMARY: The Indian government says it is investigating a website that purported to offer Muslim women for sale, the second time in less than a year that a fake online auction of this kind has sparked outrage in the country.

TITLE: Jury in Elizabeth Holmes trial will resume deliberations Monday
SUMMARY: The high-profile criminal trial of Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes will officially stretch into a new calendar year Monday when the jury entrusted with determining her fate will continue deliberations after a short respite.

TITLE: Classic BlackBerry phones will stop working January 4
SUMMARY: You soon won't be able to use that old BlackBerry phone sitting at the bottom of your drawer somewhere.

TITLE: 2021: The year of billionaires going to space
Chinese tech stocks are climbing on the last day of the year. But 2021 has been a bloodbath
SUMMARY: Chinese tech stocks got a big boost in Hong Kong on the last day of the year, but it's far from enough to make up for what has been a historically tumultuous time for the sector.

TITLE: Sirisha Bandla, India-born woman and Virgin Galactic executive, flies into space with Richard Branson
SUMMARY: Indians on Twitter — from top politicians to business executives — are celebrating one of the women who flew to the edge of space along with Richard Branson.

TITLE: Tesla recalls 475,000 vehicles due to camera and front trunk issues
SUMMARY: Over 475,000 Tesla Inc (TSLA) cars have been recalled due to technical defects that may increase the risk of accidents. Two separate recalls are in place, one regarding the rear-view camera in the Tesla Model 3 and the other involves the frunk, or front trunk, latches in the Model S.

TITLE: China's Xi'an lockdown hits some of the world's largest chipmakers
SUMMARY: Two of the world's biggest chipmakers are warning that Covid-19 outbreaks and stringent lockdowns in a major Chinese industrial hub are hampering their operations.

TITLE: After hours offline, Fortnite access has been restored
SUMMARY: After hours offline, Fortnite servers were restored at 6:50pm EST Wednesday.

TITLE: TikTok sued by content moderator who claims she developed PTSD from reviewing disturbing content
SUMMARY: A content moderator for TikTok is suing the social media platform after she says she developed psychological trauma as a result of her job, which she alleges required her to review videos featuring graphic violence, conspiracy theories and other disturbing imagery.

TITLE: How John Madden became the biggest name in video games
SUMMARY: John Madden, the former Hall of Fame NFL coach, has died. But his name lives on in one of the world's most popular video games.

TITLE: Waymo will partner with China's Geely to develop electric robotaxis
SUMMARY: Waymo, the self-driving arm of Google's parent company Alphabet, and Chinese carmaker Geely have partnered to build electric, fully autonomous ride-hailing vehicles to be used across the united States.

TITLE: Elon Musk's SpaceX satellites catch heat in China over close calls with space station
SUMMARY: Elon Musk's rocky year in China is ending on another sour note.

TITLE: Riot Games agrees to $100 million settlement in gender discrimination lawsuit
SUMMARY: Tencent Holdings' Riot Games on Monday said it has agreed to pay $100 million to settle a 2018 gender-based discrimination class-action lawsuit with California state agencies and current and former women employees.

TITLE: Alphabet CEO Pichai can be questioned in privacy lawsuit, judge rules
SUMMARY: Plaintiffs who accused Alphabet Inc's Google of unlawfully tracking their internet use while on "Incognito" browsing mode can question Chief Executive Sundar Pichai for up to two hours, a California federal judge has ruled.

TITLE: Apple closes all New York stores to browsing as Omicron cases surge
SUMMARY: Apple has closed all of its New York store locations to browsing because of a surge in Covid-19 cases. The roughly one dozen locations in the city will be limited to picking up online orders and walk-in services such as Genius Bar support.

TITLE: China plans to tighten rules on overseas IPOs
SUMMARY: China is planning to tighten restrictions for Chinese companies that want to list overseas. And while Beijing won't ban them from trading abroad altogether, life might be getting a lot tougher for firms hoping to score more foreign investment.

TITLE: The biggest tech fails of 2021
SUMMARY: For many, 2021 was a mix of hopeful and challenging, as covid vaccines became more widely available but the pandemic dragged on for another year. And while technology continued to keep us entertained and connected during the pandemic, it also made our lives harder.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes Trial: Jury says it is deadlocked on three counts
SUMMARY: The jury tasked with determining the fate of Elizabeth Holmes, the former CEO and founder of failed blood testing startup Theranos in her criminal trial, said that it is unable to come to a unanimous verdict on three of the eleven counts.

TITLE: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene says Facebook blocked her account for 24 hours
SUMMARY: Facebook has blocked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene from posting on its platform for 24 hours, the Georgia Republican said Monday.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes trial: The jury has reached a verdict
SUMMARY: The jury in the criminal trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the former CEO and founder of Theranos, has reached a verdict. Holmes was found guilty on four charges — three counts of wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud. The jury returned no verdict on three counts of wire fraud.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes found guilty on four out of 11 federal charges
SUMMARY: The jury in the criminal trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the former CEO and founder of Theranos, has reached a verdict. Holmes was found guilty on four charges — three counts of wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud. The jury returned no verdict on three counts of wire fraud. She was found not guilty on three additional charges of wire fraud and one charge of conspiracy to commit wire fraud.

The jury in the criminal trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the former CEO and founder of Theranos, has reached a verdict after a lengthy trial that kicked off last fall at a federal courthouse in San Jose presided over by Judge Edward Davila.

TITLE: The key moments from Elizabeth Holmes' trial
SUMMARY: After nearly four months of court proceedings in one of the most high-profile tech trials in recent memory, Elizabeth Holmes has been found guilty on four out of 11 federal fraud and conspiracy charges.

TITLE: AT&T and Verizon agree to postpone 5G rollout near airports by 2 weeks
SUMMARY: AT&T and Verizon have agreed to postpone their planned rollouts of 5G infrastructure near airports by two weeks, averting — for now — feared widespread disruptions to air travel and shipping as well as a potential legal battle over the matter.

TITLE: The rise and fall of Elizabeth Holmes: A timeline
SUMMARY: More than three years after Elizabeth Holmes was first indicted and nearly four months after her trial kicked off, the founder and former CEO of failed blood testing startup Theranos was found guilty on four out of 11 federal fraud and conspiracy charges.

TITLE: Classic BlackBerry phones stop working today
SUMMARY: You can no longer use that old BlackBerry phone sitting at the bottom of your drawer somewhere.

TITLE: What's next for Elizabeth Holmes?
SUMMARY: As Elizabeth Holmes heard in real time that a jury of eight men and four women had found her guilty on four counts of defrauding investors, the former Theranos CEO remained stoic.

TITLE: Smartphones, laptops and oddball gadgets: CES 2022 showcases tech's latest innovations
SUMMARY: The United States' biggest technology conference may look a little different in 2022, but it's still delivering on some innovative and wacky products that make an appearance year after year.

TITLE: Sony is gearing up to make an electric car
SUMMARY: Sony has announced plans to launch an electric car company later this year as it unveiled a new sports utility vehicle concept.

TITLE: NASA's first Artemis moon mission will have a virtual astronaut: Amazon's Alexa
Warren, Jayapal blast Google over efforts to "bully" and "sideline" DOJ's top antitrust official
SUMMARY: Google must stop attempting to intimidate US antitrust enforcers at the Justice Department, according to two congressional Democrats.

TITLE: Google Maps helps Italian police capture mafia fugitive
SUMMARY: Italian police has caught a top mafia fugitive who had been on the run for nearly 20 years thanks to the help of the Google Maps app, an investigator told Reuters on Wednesday.

TITLE: What it was like to be in the courtroom for Elizabeth Holmes' fraud trial
SUMMARY: Inside the San Jose federal courtroom, I shifted my body forward and from side to side trying to watch Elizabeth Holmes' face from the wooden bench I'd all but taken up residence in for the past four months. Like others in the courtroom Monday, I wanted to catch a glimpse of any reaction Holmes might have as she learned that jurors had found her guilty on four of 11 federal fraud and conspiracy charges.

TITLE: Republicans wasted no time dragging Big Tech into the culture wars in 2022
SUMMARY: Almost exactly one year after the Capitol insurrection that led to former President Donald Trump being suspended from Twitter, Facebook and YouTube, Big Tech was again in the political crosshairs this week for cracking down on an account from another Republican.

TITLE: On the anniversary of January 6, social media platforms are on high alert
SUMMARY: January 6 was a clear turning point for major social media companies — proving that they would, under certain circumstances, be willing to deplatform a sitting US president. But some experts worry that they still haven't done enough to address the underlying issues that allowed Trump supporters and others on the far-right to be misled and radicalized, and to get organized using their platforms.

TITLE: People desperate for Covid tests are turning to resellers online
SUMMARY: When Patrick Kennedy, a nightlife performer in New York City, recently tested positive for Covid-19, he was desperate to find more rapid tests to not only monitor his health but track when he'd be able to return to work.

TITLE: Tim Cook's compensation jumped to nearly $100 million last year
SUMMARY: Tim Cook had a very good year.

TITLE: CES 2022: 5 takeaways from the giant tech trade show
SUMMARY: CES, the closely-watched annual consumer electronics show, looked drastically different this year.

TITLE: In VR, there are no rules, so parents are making up their own
SUMMARY: Last summer, Allen Roach saw something that really disturbed him: His then-11-year-old son, Peyton, used a sword to slice off the arms and legs of characters in a virtual reality medieval fantasy game, Blade & Sorcery, then threw the dismembered digital bodies off a bridge.

TITLE: Space industry year ahead: SpaceX's Mars rocket, tourism, and more billionaire battles
Google ordered to turn over documents related to anti-union efforts in NLRB case
SUMMARY: A judge has ordered Google to turn over hundreds of internal documents — many related to its efforts to quash an employee union — as part of a National Labor Relations Board case over the tech giant's firing of former employees.

TITLE: Facebook parent Meta delays return to office and will require booster shots
SUMMARY: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is delaying its return to US offices until March 28 and will require proof of Covid-19 booster shots for workers in those offices. The company already requires that in-office workers be vaccinated.

TITLE: Judge rejects Facebook's request to dismiss FTC antitrust complaint
SUMMARY: US antitrust officials can continue their case to break up Meta, Facebook's parent company, a federal judge ruled on Tuesday, dealing a blow to the social media giant, which had argued the complaint should be dismissed.

TITLE: More than 80 fact-checking organizations call out YouTube's 'insufficient' response to misinformation
SUMMARY: A group of more than 80 fact-checking organizations from around the world has called YouTube "one of the major conduits of online disinformation and misinformation worldwide" and wants the platform to do more to address the problem.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes sentencing may take place after Labor Day
SUMMARY: Elizabeth Holmes, the former CEO of Theranos who was convicted earlier this month on four out of 11 federal fraud and conspiracy charges, may not be sentenced until after Labor Day, more than a full year after her trial began, according to a court filing Tuesday.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes sentencing hearing set for September 26
SUMMARY: Elizabeth Holmes, the former CEO of Theranos who was convicted earlier this month on four out of 11 federal fraud and conspiracy charges, will not be sentenced until September 26, according to a new filing.

TITLE: Taiwan's TSMC reports record quarterly profit, will boost chip spending in 2022
SUMMARY: Taiwanese chip firm TSMC expects strong growth to accelerate in coming years due to booming semiconductor demand, as the tech giant on Thursday reported a record quarterly profit and said it plans to spend at least a third more than last year.

TITLE: Facebook faces $3.2 billion UK class action over market dominance
SUMMARY: Social media giant Facebook, now known as Meta Platforms, faces a 2.3 billion pound plus ($3.2 billion plus) class action in Britain over allegations it abused its market dominance by exploiting the personal data of 44 million users.

TITLE: Facebook, Google CEOs were aware of formal advertising market deal, according to court filing
SUMMARY: Chief executives of Alphabet Inc's Google and Facebook were aware of a deal to carve up part of the online advertising market, according to an amended complaint filed by Texas and other states that have filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google.

TITLE: North Korean hackers said to have stolen nearly $400 million in cryptocurrency last year
SUMMARY: North Korean hackers stole nearly $400 million worth of cryptocurrency in 2021, making it one of the most lucrative years to date for cybercriminals in the severely isolated country, according to a new report.

TITLE: Apple to require employee proof of Covid-19 booster
SUMMARY: Apple Inc will require retail and corporate employees to provide proof of a Covid-19 booster shot, The Verge reported on Saturday, citing an internal email.

TITLE: A robot is killing weeds by zapping them with electricity
SUMMARY: UK-based startup Small Robot Company has developed robots to rid land of unwanted weeds without using chemicals and heavy machinery.

TITLE: Here's how US lawmakers could finally rein in Facebook
SUMMARY: After years of talk, it remains unclear if or when US lawmakers might actually pass new laws or take other regulatory action — or what exactly it would look like if they did.

TITLE: FAA clears some commercial planes for low-visibility landings after warning 5G could interfere with instruments
SUMMARY: Federal officials are easing up some of the restrictions on commercial airliners set to take effect this week when new 5G technology comes online.

TITLE: Amazon drops plan to ban Visa credit cards in UK
SUMMARY: Amazon said on Monday it would not stop accepting UK-issued Visa Inc credit cards on its British website later this month as it had proposed, adding that it was working with Visa to resolve a dispute over payment fees.
Sports Illustrated model Brooks Nader is one of several women who claim they were being tracked by an Apple AirTag.

TITLE: Parents of worker killed in tornado that hit Amazon facility are suing the company for wrongful death
SUMMARY: The parents of Austin McEwen, one of the six victims killed after a tornado pummeled an Amazon warehouse in Edwardsville, Illinois, last month, said Monday during a press conference that they are suing Amazon over the alleged wrongful death of their son.

TITLE: Airlines ask Biden administration for 'immediate intervention' on 5G
SUMMARY: Executives from the nation's largest airlines asked the Biden administration for "immediate intervention" in the planned rollout of 5G technology near major airports on Wednesday, warning of dire transportation and economic consequences.

TITLE: Microsoft to acquire Activision Blizzard in $68.7 billion deal
SUMMARY: Microsoft on Tuesday announced plans to acquire Activision Blizzard in a blockbuster deal worth nearly $70 billion. It's one of the biggest acquisitions in the tech industry in recent years, one that will boost Microsoft's standing in the growing gaming industry but could be complicated by recent concerns about Activision's toxic culture.

TITLE: AT&T delays launching 5G near some airports after airlines ask Biden to intervene
SUMMARY: AT&T announced Tuesday that it would delay activating 5G on some towers around certain airports. The wireless technology's rollout near major airports had been scheduled for Wednesday, but airlines warned of dire consequences for transportation and the economy.

TITLE: AT&T, Verizon delay launching 5G near some airports after airlines ask Biden to intervene
SUMMARY: AT&T and Verizon announced Tuesday that they would delay activating 5G on some towers around certain airports. The wireless technology's rollout near major airports had been scheduled for Wednesday, but airlines warned of dire consequences for transportation and the economy.

TITLE: Microsoft's Activision Blizzard deal poses 'monumental challenge' to Sony
SUMMARY: Microsoft's blockbuster purchase of video game developer Activision Blizzard could pose a serious threat for Sony.

TITLE: What is C-band 5G? Verizon and AT&T are flipping on the switch in the US
SUMMARY: The next-generation of wireless technology is now even faster for 5G users in some parts of the country.

TITLE: The CEO who fired 900 employees over Zoom is coming back
SUMMARY: The CEO of Better.com, best known for firing 900 employees over Zoom just before Christmas, is coming back to work.

TITLE: Microsoft deal to deliver $390 million payday for Activision's embattled CEO
SUMMARY: Activision Blizzard Inc's Chief Executive Officer Bobby Kotick has gone from defending his handling of sexual harassment and discrimination claims at the video game maker to preparing to walk away with a windfall of at least $390 million.

TITLE: Sony takes a big hit in the console wars
SUMMARY: Microsoft's blockbuster purchase of video game developer Activision Blizzard could pose a serious threat for Sony.

TITLE: The 5G-airline snafu: Everything we know
SUMMARY: The attempt to roll out amped up mobile service across the United States has been a bit of a mess. The aviation industry and transportation regulators are worried about new 5G antennas interfering with a key type of aircraft altimeter that's essential for landing planes in bad weather. But wireless carriers and telecom regulators have said there's nothing to fear.

TITLE: Twitter is rolling out verified NFT profile pictures
SUMMARY: Twitter on Thursday began rolling out a feature that will let some users set NFTs that they own as their profile picture to signal their investment in the emerging digital art space. The move makes Twitter one of the best-known tech platforms so far to launch a feature for the flashy NFT trend.

TITLE: A group of Activision Blizzard employees is demanding union recognition
SUMMARY: Workers at an Activision Blizzard-owned game studio announced plans on Friday to form what would be the first union at the troubled gaming company.

TITLE: IBM is selling off its Watson Health assets
SUMMARY: IBM said Friday that it will sell off the healthcare data and analytics assets housed under its Watson Health unit to private equity firm Francisco Partners.

TITLE: How to access AT&T and Verizon's new super fast 5G networks
SUMMARY: Many mobile device users in the United States now have access to blazing-fast internet speeds stemming from the rollout of Verizon and AT&T's new C-band 5G networks earlier this week.

TITLE: An airline crisis over 5G was mostly averted this week. But it's not over yet
Ireland's data centers are an economic lifeline. But environmentalists say they're wrecking the planet
SUMMARY: In the west of Ireland lies a medieval market town, its roots steeped in legend. Beyond the labyrinth of narrow streets of the center are the chimney stacks of housing developments that still puff coal and peat. Past those homes, on the outskirts of Ennis, is an unremarkable but huge plot of land, nestled between a power station and farmland where cattle and sheep graze. This is where a mysterious company has applied to develop a new data center the size of 22 American football fields.

TITLE: Australia says WeChat has removed the account of its prime minister
SUMMARY: Australia has accused WeChat of taking down Prime Minister Scott Morrison's account and redirecting his followers to a site that claims to provide information for Chinese Australians.

TITLE: Meta is building an AI supercomputer
SUMMARY: Facebook has long bet that artificial intelligence can help it with the difficult task of moderating posts from its billions of users. Now its parent company is taking a step that could move it closer to that elusive goal: building its first supercomputer.

TITLE: Four attorneys general sue Google for 'deceptive' location tracking
SUMMARY: A bipartisan group of attorneys general sued Google on Monday, alleging that the technology giant has used "dark patterns" and deceptive practices to track users' physical location even when those users have made efforts to block Google from doing so.

TITLE: Australia says WeChat has removed the account of its Prime Minister
SUMMARY: Australia has accused WeChat of taking down Prime Minister Scott Morrison's account and redirecting his followers to a site that claims to provide information for Chinese Australians.

TITLE: Google offers new replacement for advertising cookies
SUMMARY: Alphabet Inc's Google on Tuesday announced its second try at enabling advertisers to buy ads based on users' browsing interests without having to rely on what it has described as privacy-invasive tracking cookies. FLoC, their first attempt at replacing cookies, will be taken over by Topic.

TITLE: Some manufacturers have less than 5 days' supply of computer chips, Commerce Department warns
SUMMARY: Some manufacturers that rely on semiconductors are down to less than five days' worth of inventory, according to a report released Tuesday by the Commerce Department, in the latest indication of the extent of the computer chip shortage.

TITLE: Tim Cook allegedly stalked by woman who trespassed and sent photos of a loaded gun
SUMMARY: Apple has been granted a restraining order against a woman who allegedly threatened, harassed and stalked CEO Tim Cook for more than a year.

TITLE: China pledges 'purification' of the internet ahead of the Beijing Winter Olympics and the Lunar New Year
SUMMARY: China's top cybersecurity regulator is vowing to crack down on "illegal" online content as part of a campaign to clean up the internet ahead of the Beijing Winter Olympics and one of the country's most important annual holidays.

TITLE: Wordle-spoiling bot taken down by Twitter
SUMMARY: Twitter has suspended an annoying bot that automatically responded with the next day's solution when people posted their Wordle scores on the platform.

TITLE: Gates Foundation adds board members following Bill and Melinda's divorce
SUMMARY: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation named four new members to its board of trustees on Wednesday, marking the first outsiders added to the charity's board in its two-decade history.

TITLE: Amazon faces possible union election at New York warehouse
SUMMARY: Workers at an Amazon warehouse in Staten Island have shown enough support to hold a union election, the National Labor Relations Board confirmed on Wednesday.

TITLE: Apple is back on top in smartphone sales worldwide after a record win in China
SUMMARY: Apple has once again become the top-selling smartphone brand in top market China, along with the rest of the world.

TITLE: Forget Zoom school. For some students, class is in session in VR
SUMMARY: Jeremy Bailenson has studied virtual reality for decades. But it wasn't until last year that the Stanford professor felt the technology was good enough that he could actually teach a class in VR.

TITLE: Microsoft makes a big bet that it can fix Activision Blizzard's troubled culture
SUMMARY: Microsoft's nearly $70 billion deal to buy Activision Blizzard could make it a leader in gaming. But it also risks creating a new headache for the tech giant in a key part of its operations: corporate culture.

TITLE: Apple posted record holiday quarter sales despite supply constraints
SUMMARY: Apple posted record revenue during the all-important holiday quarter even as it continued to grapple with supply chain shortages.

TITLE: The IRS website will soon require facial recognition to log in to your account
SUMMARY: The next time you try to log in to the Internal Revenue Service's website you'll be urged to use facial-recognition software to verify you are who you say you are.

TITLE: US authorities block China Unicom from the nation's telecom market
SUMMARY: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday voted to ban China Unicom, a state-owned Chinese telecommunications carrier, from offering telecom services in the United States.

TITLE: Google is investing another $1 billion in India's smartphone market
SUMMARY: Google is investing up to $1 billion in a major Indian telecom company, a move it hopes will drive down the cost of smartphones in a huge and rapidly expanding market.

TITLE: UK companies told to bolster defenses against Russian cyberattacks
SUMMARY: UK companies and organizations have been urged to bolster their defenses against potential Russian cyberattacks as Moscow masses military forces on the Ukrainian border.

TITLE: Telecom regulator blocks China Unicom from US market
SUMMARY: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday voted to ban China Unicom, a state-owned Chinese telecommunications carrier, from offering telecom services in the United States.

TITLE: How last week's 5G deployment went so wrong
SUMMARY: From canceled flights to dire warnings of a stalled shipping economy, this was not how the rollout of 5G networks was supposed to go.

TITLE: Apple Music trolls Spotify by calling itself 'the home of Neil Young'
SUMMARY: Just a day after Spotify agreed to remove Neil Young's music from its service, Apple Music trolled its streaming rival by giving the musician some rock star treatment.

TITLE: Elon Musk is placing a bet on robots. It could be a long time coming
SUMMARY: Tesla CEO Elon Musk said Wednesday that he believes the company's goal of a humanoid robot is the most important thing it's working on.

TITLE: Meta pauses new users from joining analytics tool CrowdTangle
SUMMARY: Facebook's parent company Meta Platforms Inc has paused new users from joining its social media tracking tool CrowdTangle due to staffing constraints.

TITLE: A new crop of shopping tools aims to help consumers beat the supply chain crunch
SUMMARY: A small but dedicated community of programmers, journalists and social media content creators has sprung up to announce whenever a big retailer has restocked more product.

TITLE: Shanghai metro sparks Covid panic with festive red QR codes
SUMMARY: A Chinese subway system's attempt to spread some Lunar New Year cheer backfired over the weekend, as panicked passengers mistook seasonal red QR codes for positive Covid tests.

TITLE: Alice, the first all-electric passenger airplane, prepares to fly
SUMMARY: What hopes to be the world's first all-electric passenger aircraft is preparing to take flight.

TITLE: Sony to acquire video game studio Bungie in $3.6 billion deal
SUMMARY: Sony is acquiring Bungie, the video game studio that created hit franchises such as "Halo" and "Destiny," in a $3.6 billion deal that further centralizes the rapidly consolidating game industry.

TITLE: Facebook's dream of creating its own global cryptocurrency officially comes to an end
SUMMARY: In June 2019, after years of being under scrutiny for the impact its platforms have on society, Facebook unveiled one of its most ambitious projects yet: a cryptocurrency called Libra, which would be backed by an international consortium of companies. The effort had such lofty goals as providing financial services to the underbanked and extending the social media company's mission of connecting the world into the burgeoning market for digital money.

TITLE: Google stock jumps 8% after blowout quarter fueled by strong ad sales
SUMMARY: Despite being one of the biggest online advertising giants, Google's ad business is still growing at a rapid clip.

TITLE: 3G networks are shutting down soon. A scramble to get users to upgrade is underway
SUMMARY: Aaron Hommell bought his 3G iPhone 5 in 2014 and kept it for more than seven years, holding onto it even after the screen cracked and a long list of faster models hit the market. Then a year ago, AT&T began sending him emails that the company would be shutting down its 3G network and moving its subscribers to its higher-speed 4G and 5G networks.

TITLE: Meta shares plummet 20% after posting rare profit decline
SUMMARY: Facebook rattled investors on Wednesday by posting a rare profit decline, driven by the company's heavy spending on its vision for a so-called metaverse while simultaneously confronting advertising challenges on its existing services.

TITLE: China's JD.com CEO joins billionaire charity rush with $2.3 billion share pledge
SUMMARY: JD.com founder and CEO Richard Liu will donate company shares worth about $2.34 billion to charity, the Chinese e-commerce giant said on Wednesday, adding to a list of similar philanthropic pledges from the country's top tech billionaires.

TITLE: PlayStation and Switch sales are suffering as the gaming wars heat up
SUMMARY: Two of the world's biggest video game companies are feeling the pressure as the console wars heat up.

TITLE: Nintendo Switch tops lifetime sales of Wii console
SUMMARY: Nintendo Co Ltd sold 18.95 million Switch video game consoles in the nine months to the end of December, the Japanese company said on Thursday, taking total sales past 100 million and beating the lifetime sales of its Wii console.

TITLE: Melinda French Gates reportedly won't give bulk of her wealth to Gates Foundation
SUMMARY: Melinda French Gates may be shifting her approach to how she gives away her vast wealth following her high-profile divorce last year from Microsoft founder Bill Gates.

TITLE: Meta's market value just dropped by more than most companies are worth
SUMMARY: Meta Platforms, the company formerly known as Facebook, is on pace for what would be the worst trading day in its history as a public company.

TITLE: Wag, a dog-walking startup that once raised $300 million from a single investor, is going public through a SPAC
SUMMARY: Wag, a dog-walking startup that once received $300 million from a single investor only to stumble in executing its strategy, is set to go public in a deal valued not much higher than that one investment.

TITLE: Amazon is raising the price of annual Prime memberships to $139
SUMMARY: Amazon is raising the price of its annual Prime subscriptions from $119 to $139 per year, the company announced along with its earnings report Thursday

TITLE: MacKenzie Scott donates $133.5 million to educational nonprofit Communities in School
SUMMARY: MacKenzie Scott has donated $133.5 million to educational nonprofit Communities in School, an organization that helps students navigate issues inside and outside of the classroom.

TITLE: Snap recovers from Apple privacy changes, shares surge 50%
SUMMARY: Snap Inc on Thursday said its advertising business bounced back from the effects of Apple Inc's privacy changes faster than it expected, and shares of the company skyrocketed 50% as it provided a first quarter outlook that surpassed analyst estimates.

TITLE: Australian mining magnate takes legal action against Facebook over scam ads
SUMMARY: Billionaire mining magnate Andrew Forrest is taking legal action against Facebook in Australia after he claims the company failed to remove scam advertisements that used his image.

TITLE: Mark Zuckerberg is in danger of losing his top 10 billionaire ranking
SUMMARY: The historic collapse in Meta's shares this week has wiped $31 billion off Mark Zuckerberg's personal wealth, taking him down three places on Bloomberg's list of the world's richest people.

TITLE: At an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, a milestone union election is set to begin all over again
SUMMARY: Last year, an improbable organizing effort among Amazon warehouse workers in a central Alabama suburb led to a high-profile push to create what would have been the first US union in Amazon's history. While the vote indicated the union push had failed, the results were thrown out.

TITLE: The International Space Station could fall from the sky in 2031. What happens next?
SUMMARY: Since the earliest days of the International Space Station, NASA has been exploring ways to get the private sector more involved, with the hope of bringing a capitalistic bent to a program that eats up a couple billion dollars worth of taxpayer money each year.

TITLE: Suspected Chinese hackers hit News Corp with 'persistent cyberattack' in January
SUMMARY: News Corp suffered a "persistent cyberattack" in January, the company said Friday, and investigators believe Chinese spies may be responsible.

TITLE: Meta is giving avatars a four-foot buffer zone to cut back on VR harassment
SUMMARY: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, has a new feature aimed at cutting down on harassment and assault in virtual reality: It will give avatars in its Horizon Worlds social app and Horizon Venues events app an invisible "personal boundary" of four feet to stop others from getting too close.

TITLE: Suspected Chinese hackers hit News Corp with 'persistent cyberattack'
SUMMARY: News Corp suffered a "persistent cyberattack" in January, the company said Friday, and investigators believe Chinese spies may be responsible.

TITLE: Relativity is 3D printing rockets and raising billions. Will its technology work?
SUMMARY: Tim Ellis, an unassuming 31-year-old with glasses who shuffles around his sprawling rocket factory in designer sneakers, has what every space company founder longs for: a seemingly endless well of investors willing to pour money into his company.

TITLE: Facebook has successfully overhauled its business before. This time will be harder
SUMMARY: Ahead of its 2012 initial public offering, Facebook was in trouble. Its revenue growth was slowing, expenses were surging and it was falling behind competitors in the transition to smartphones and other mobile devices.

TITLE: PriceRunner sues Google for 2.1 billion euros
SUMMARY: Swedish price comparison firm PriceRunner said on Monday it was suing Alphabet-owned Google for about 2.1 billion euros ($2.4 billion), the latest firm to take legal action alleging the search giant manipulated search results.

TITLE: Amazon more than doubles salary caps to $350,000 for US white-collar employees
SUMMARY: Amazon is dramatically increasing salary caps for its US-based technology and corporate workforce, in a nod to how the pandemic has exacerbated an already fierce competition for talent nationwide.

TITLE: IRS halts plan to require facial recognition for logging in to user accounts
SUMMARY: The Internal Revenue Service is halting a plan that would have required taxpayers to verify their identities with facial recognition software before signing on to its website following backlash from lawmakers and privacy groups.

TITLE: Peter Thiel to step down from Facebook's board
SUMMARY: Peter Thiel, one of Facebook's longest-serving and most controversial board members, plans to step down from the company's board later this year, the company said Monday.

TITLE: The biggest computer chip deal in history has fallen apart
SUMMARY: SoftBank's record-breaking sale of a prized chip designer to Nvidia has officially been called off.

TITLE: The biggest chip deal in history has fallen apart
SUMMARY: SoftBank's record-breaking sale of a prized chip designer to Nvidia has officially been called off.

TITLE: Elon Musk launched his own Tesla roadster to space four years ago. Where is it now?
GM's robotaxis are only coming out after dark
SUMMARY: Cruise, the self-driving subsidiary of General Motors, started offering robotaxi rides this week in San Francisco. Anyone can sign up for the chance to be selected to get a ride in a self-driving car, provided they don't mind staying up late. Cruise's robotaxis are generally only operating from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m, according to the company. Access is limited, so people are likely to find themselves idling on Cruise's wait list. So far Cruise says it's given more than 500 rides.

TITLE: Apple will let shoppers pay merchants by holding phones together
SUMMARY: Apple on Tuesday said it plans to introduce a contactless payment option later this year that will let businesses use iPhones to process transactions in stores without any additional hardware, competing with services like Square.

TITLE: TikTok says it will strengthen policies in effort to prevent spread of hoaxes and dangerous challenges
SUMMARY: TikTok announced Tuesday that it will strengthen efforts to regulate dangerous content, including harmful hoaxes and content that promotes eating disorders and hateful ideologies. The platform plans to use creators to spread awareness of negative hoaxes, broaden the scope of banned eating disorder content and add clarity on prohibited speech and behaviors.

TITLE: After face-recognition backlash, ID.me says government agencies will get more verification options
SUMMARY: ID.me CEO and founder Blake Hall said in a press release Tuesday that the company is making it possible for government agencies to give users the option to verify their identity by talking to a human agent, rather than using ID.me's software.

TITLE: What to expect at the Samsung Galaxy Unpacked event
SUMMARY: Samsung is expected to unveil three new Galaxy S devices at its annual Unpacked product launch event on Wednesday.

TITLE: Cap'n Crunch and Lunchables are showing up in video games now
SUMMARY: Gaming is big business. And snack makers want in.

TITLE: Peter Thiel's Facebook exit clears the way for his Republican ambitions
SUMMARY: Peter Thiel, the controversial billionaire tech founder and investor, has used his fortune to encourage kids to skip college, to back a lawsuit that bankrupted Gawker Media and to donate to the presidential campaign of Donald Trump when many in Silicon Valley were strongly opposed to him.

TITLE: Goodbye Samsung Galaxy Note. Hello Galaxy S22 Ultra
SUMMARY: Samsung's Galaxy Note smartphone line appears to be discontinued. But for those who miss it, the Note lives on in one of Samsung's new flagship devices.

TITLE: Peter Thiel is backing a new generation of Trump-aligned Republicans
SUMMARY: Peter Thiel, the controversial billionaire tech founder and investor, has used his fortune to encourage kids to skip college, to back a lawsuit that bankrupted Gawker Media and to donate to the presidential campaign of Donald Trump when many in Silicon Valley were strongly opposed to him.

TITLE: Tesla says California plans to sue over alleged discrimination, harassment
SUMMARY: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing will sue Tesla, alleging systematic racial discrimination and harassment, the automaker said in a blog post Wednesday.

TITLE: Microsoft tries to win over regulators for massive Activision Blizzard deal with new app store commitments
SUMMARY: Microsoft is trying to persuade regulators to approve its $68.7 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard with a series of new app store commitments that it says will put the company "on the right side of history" as policymakers worldwide debate new laws to force competition open in digital marketplaces.

TITLE: SpaceX will lose up to 40 satellites it just launched due to a solar storm
SUMMARY: Up to 40 of SpaceX's Starlink satellites are expected to fall out of orbit thanks to some inopportune timing: The company launched the satellites directly into a solar storm.

TITLE: Uber's business is over the pandemic slump
SUMMARY: Uber's business is showing signs that it's moving past the pandemic slowdown.

TITLE: French watchdog says Google Analytics poses data privacy risks
SUMMARY: Google Analytics, the world's most widely used web analytics service developed by Alphabet's Google (GOOG), risks giving U.S. intelligence services access to French website users' data, France's watchdog CNIL said on Thursday.

TITLE: Elon Musk to give first Mars rocket update in two years
SUMMARY: SpaceX CEO Elon Musk is expected on Thursday to give the most thorough update in two years about SpaceX's plans for Starship, the gargantuan rocket at the heart of Musk's interplanetary travel ambitions.

TITLE: Apple plans AirTag updates to curb unwanted tracking
SUMMARY: Apple said Thursday it plans to add more safeguards to AirTags to cut down on unwanted tracking following reports that the devices have been used to stalk people and steal cars.

TITLE: Elon Musk gives hotly anticipated Starship update, but it's light on new details
SUMMARY: SpaceX CEO Elon Musk spoke for over an hour Thursday night in a hotly anticipated discussion about Starship, which the company hopes will one day take humans to Mars and that will play a key role in NASA's plans to return humans to the moon for the first time in a half century. Still, not many new details were shared.

TITLE: A controversial bill to protect kids online just advanced in the Senate. Here's what you should know
SUMMARY: A controversial bill targeting how tech platforms and websites handle child sexual abuse material cleared a key hurdle on Thursday as a Senate panel voted to approve the legislation despite vocal objections from civil rights groups who say the proposal as written will backfire and harm all internet users.

TITLE: Google's advertising tech targeted in European publishers' complaint
SUMMARY: Google on Friday was targeted in an antitrust complaint by the European Publishers Council over its digital advertising business, potentially strengthening EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager's investigation into the issue.

TITLE: The end of a wild pandemic ride: What it was like for Peloton employees who lost their jobs this week
SUMMARY: Late Monday night, some Peloton staffers noticed they were unable to access work productivity apps like Slack and Okta, which they used regularly on the job. Peloton's employees had been told about a scheduled maintenance window that might cause service outages, according to one employee, but that didn't stop others from bracing for the worst.

TITLE: Amazon rolls back mask mandate for some vaccinated warehouse workers
SUMMARY: Amazon will no longer require its fully vaccinated warehouse employees to wear face masks at work in states that have eased up on mask mandates, the company said in an internal memo Thursday.

TITLE: What to expect at Apple's first product event of the year
SUMMARY: Apple is about to hold its first big product event of 2022 and the focus will be on performance. That likely means faster chips, more devices with 5G connectivity and more powerful cameras.

TITLE: Russia says it's blocking access to Facebook
SUMMARY: Russia moved to block access to Facebook within its borders on Friday, seeking to shut down the world's biggest social media platform and drawing a rebuke from the Biden administration.

TITLE: Russia's version of Google warns it may not be able to pay its debts
SUMMARY: Russia's biggest search engine could collapse as financial fallout from the invasion of Ukraine spreads.

TITLE: Google halts all advertising in Russia
SUMMARY: Google has suspended all advertising in Russia, the company confirmed to CNN Friday.

TITLE: SpaceX sent Starlink internet terminals to Ukraine. Users should be cautious
SUMMARY: SpaceX CEO Elon Musk sent a truckload of Starlink antennas — which can be used to connect to the company's satellite-based internet service — to Ukraine this week, responding to a plea from the country's vice prime minister amid fears that Ukrainians could lose internet access if Russia continues its attacks on communication infrastructure.

TITLE: How Mark Zuckerberg is trying to reduce his exposure to public scrutiny
SUMMARY: When Russia moved to "partially restrict" Facebook access in the country last week, drawing the social network deeper into an international conflict, it prompted a defiant response from the company's most visible representative on the world stage.

TITLE: Coinbase, Binance resist calls to kick Russians off crypto platforms
SUMMARY: Two of the world's biggest cryptocurrency exchanges, Coinbase Global Inc and Binance, rejected calls on Friday for a blanket ban on all Russian users to stop their platforms from being used as a way round Western sanctions.

TITLE: Russian space chief says Russia will no longer sell rocket engines to the US
SUMMARY: Russia's space agency, Roscosmos, will no longer deliver Russian-made rocket engines to the United States, Roscosmos head Dmitry Rogozin said on state television, ending a decades-long relationship between US and Russian rocket makers.

TITLE: UK satellite firm refuses Russian ultimatum on launch
SUMMARY: A Russian ultimatum was met with swift dismissal as the war in Ukraine extends to outer space.

TITLE: Ukraine's request to cut off Russia from the global internet has been rejected
SUMMARY: The international non-profit that coordinates management of the internet told Ukraine it will not intervene in the country's war with Russia, rebuffing a request to cut Russia off from the global internet.

TITLE: Group of attorneys general announce investigation into TikTok's impact on young Americans
SUMMARY: A nationwide group of state attorneys general announced an investigation into TikTok's impact on young Americans Tuesday, adding to the steady drumbeat of political pressure being applied to social media platforms.

TITLE: Google will ask employees to spend three days a week in the office starting April 4
SUMMARY: Google is giving its employees one more month of being fully remote before requiring them back in the office at least three days a week.

TITLE: Amazon is closing all of its physical bookstores
SUMMARY: First, Amazon killed traditional bookstores. Then it opened its own. Now, Amazon is doing away with its bookstores.

TITLE: Ukraine wants Russia to be severed from the global internet. Experts say it's a risky idea
SUMMARY: Over the past week, Ukraine's government has pressured major tech platforms to rethink how they operate with Russia, and it has been pretty successful. Social media companies have reduced the reach of Russian state-backed media outlets, for example, and Apple has stopped selling its products and limited some services in Russia.

TITLE: Apple sets date for first product launch of the year
SUMMARY: Apple is gearing up for its first big product event of the year.

TITLE: Fitbit recalls 1.7 million smartwatches due to burn hazard
SUMMARY: Fitbit is recalling 1.7 million smartwatches due to a potential burn hazard, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday.

TITLE: Steve Wozniak's new venture takes aim at space junk
EU checking if cryptoassets are being used to bust Russian sanctions
SUMMARY: The European Commission is studying whether cryptoassets are being used to get around financial sanctions imposed on Russian banks following the country's invasion of Ukraine, a senior European Union official said on Wednesday.

TITLE: Apple suspends all product sales in Russia
SUMMARY: Apple has stopped selling all of its products in Russia due to the invasion of Ukraine, the company announced Tuesday.

TITLE: Chartered buses, salary advances, hotlines: How tech companies are helping their workers in Ukraine
SUMMARY: In recent years, Ukraine has increasingly positioned itself as a tech hub, with a number of global companies leveraging its formidable IT outsourcing industry or setting up their own operations in the country. But Russia's invasion of Ukraine has forced companies to scramble to get workers out.

TITLE: Netflix quits Russia and TikTok won't allow new posts
SUMMARY: Netflix and TikTok are suspending all or part of their services in Russia, adding to a long list of companies boycotting the country over its war in Ukraine.

TITLE: WeWork says it is finalizing plans to divest its Russia operations
SUMMARY: WeWork said Monday that it is planning to divest its operations in Russia, one week after its CEO said the real estate company's "assets do incredibly well" there and he didn't think it would need to pull out of the country.

TITLE: Activists pushed the IRS to drop facial recognition. They won, but they're not done yet
SUMMARY: In mid-February, privacy and digital rights activists were buzzing about a recent victory: Earlier in the month, the Internal Revenue Service said it would back away from a controversial plan to force taxpayers to use facial-recognition software before they could log in to its website.

TITLE: The digital Iron Curtain: How Russia's internet could soon start to look a lot like China's
SUMMARY: Like much else about the country, Russia's internet has long straddled East and West.

TITLE: Apple set to show off new products at first big event of the year
SUMMARY: Apple is about to hold its first big product event of the year.

TITLE: Google is buying cybersecurity firm Mandiant for $5.4 billion
SUMMARY: Google on Tuesday announced it has agreed to buy cybersecurity firm Mandiant for around $5.4 billion, one of the largest acquisitions in the tech giant's history and a big bet that helping companies better address cyber threats can bolster its cloud computing business.

TITLE: Live updates: Apple holds its first product event of the year
Apple unveils first budget 5G iPhone
SUMMARY: Apple holds its first big product event of the year.

TITLE: Spotify, Discord experience widespread disruption
SUMMARY: Spotify and Discord appear to be experiencing disruptions to their services.

TITLE: Tinder is making criminal background checks available on your dates
SUMMARY: Tinder wants to help people surface red flags about potential dates through quick and affordable criminal background checks.

TITLE: Amazon may face criminal liability for lying to Congress, House lawmakers allege
SUMMARY: House lawmakers who spent much of 2019 and 2020 probing Amazon for possible antitrust violations now accuse the tech giant of lying to Congress and want the Justice Department to investigate "potentially criminal conduct" from the company and some of its executives.

TITLE: US charges two siblings in $124 million cryptocurrency fraud
SUMMARY: US authorities on Tuesday filed criminal charges against a cryptocurrency executive and civil charges against him and his sister, accusing them of defrauding retail investors out of millions of dollars with a digital token known as Ormeus Coin.

TITLE: Magic Leap raised billions but its headset flopped. Now it's trying again
SUMMARY: Magic Leap is no longer aiming the product at developers and other early adopters who it had hoped would come up with compelling uses for it (and then, perhaps, drive consumers to pick it up). Instead, it's focusing on a narrow range of companies that might find its AR offering more useful and also be less intimidated by the price tag, which has yet to be announced but will continue to run more than $2,000 per headset.

TITLE: Facebook and Instagram to temporarily allow calls for violence against Russians
SUMMARY: Meta Platforms will allow Facebook and Instagram users in some countries to call for violence against Russians and Russian soldiers in the context of the Ukraine invasion, according to internal emails seen by Reuters on Thursday, in a temporary change to its hate speech policy.

TITLE: Facebook temporarily allows posts on Ukraine war calling for violence against 'Russian invaders'
SUMMARY: Meta Platforms will allow Facebook and Instagram users in some countries to call for violence against Russians and Russian soldiers in the context of the Ukraine invasion, according to internal emails seen by Reuters on Thursday, in a temporary change to its hate speech policy.

TITLE: Russia opens criminal case against Meta following temporary hate speech policy change
SUMMARY: Russia's Investigative Committee has opened a criminal case against Facebook parent company Meta Platforms accusing the company's employees of "illegal calls for murder and violence" against Russian citizens, according to a statement the committee published Friday.

TITLE: Ukraine halts half of world's neon output for chips, clouding outlook
SUMMARY: Ukraine's two leading suppliers of neon, which produce about half the world's supply of the key ingredient for making chips, have halted their operations as Moscow has sharpened its attack on the country, threatening to raise prices and aggravate the semiconductor shortage.

TITLE: The US dollar could go digital. Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: As technology continues to revolutionize the way people live, work and spend, central banks around the globe have kicked off efforts to reinvent their local currencies for the digital era. Now, the United States is the latest to signal "urgency" in researching a potential digital version of its dollar via a Central Bank Digital Currency, or CBDC.

TITLE: 'This is different': Why internet backbone services are cutting off Russia
SUMMARY: Big tech platforms have joined the global backlash against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, with Facebook, Google, Twitter, Spotify, Netflix and others placing at least partial restrictions on Russian content — if not exiting (or getting themselves blocked) altogether.

TITLE: Two ultra-fast delivery startups shut down in one week
SUMMARY: Fridge No More, a startup that offered fast delivery with no fee regardless of size order, told employees this week that it was shutting down after a deal with a potential buyer fell through.

TITLE: Russian internet users are learning to beat Putin's internet crackdown
SUMMARY: A digital Iron Curtain may be descending on Russia, as President Vladimir Putin struggles to control the narrative about his war in Ukraine. The Kremlin has already moved to block Facebook and Twitter, and its latest step in that direction came Friday as the government announced plans to block Instagram in the country, as well.

TITLE: Instagram users in Russia are told service will cease at midnight
SUMMARY: Instagram users in Russia have been notified that the service will cease as of midnight on Sunday after its owner Meta Platforms said last week it would allow social media users in Ukraine to post messages such as "Death to the Russian invaders".

TITLE: Apple supplier Foxconn halts operations in Shenzhen as China locks down tech hub
SUMMARY: Foxconn, one of Apple's biggest suppliers, has suspended operations in Shenzhen as China locks down the technology hub and several other regions to contain the country's worst Covid-19 outbreak in two years.

TITLE: Pete Davidson and five paying customers to fly on Jeff Bezos' suborbital rocket
SUMMARY: Pete Davidson will become the latest celebrity to fly to space with Jeff Bezos' rocket company, Blue Origin, in a brief, suborbital flight slated for later this month.

TITLE: Meta says it doesn't allow calls for assassinating heads of state
SUMMARY: Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, issued a reminder on Sunday that it prohibits calls on its platforms for the assassination of high-ranking world leaders, following intense scrutiny of the company's decision last week to relax hate speech policies in Ukraine.

TITLE: Elizabeth Holmes' No. 2 and ex-boyfriend is about to have his day in court
SUMMARY: More than two months after Theranos founder and former CEO Elizabeth Holmes was found guilty on four of 11 charges in her criminal fraud case, the trial of her ex-boyfriend and second-in-command at the failed blood testing company is set to begin.

TITLE: Lyft, like Uber, plans to add a fuel surcharge
SUMMARY: Lyft on Monday said it plans to add a small fee on rides to help drivers deal with rising gas prices across the country, days after Uber laid out its plans to do the same.

TITLE: NASA says American aboard International Space Station will come back on Russian rocket 'for sure'
SUMMARY: NASA said Monday that NASA astronaut Mark Vande Hei will return from the ISS later this month aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft as previously planned. The space agency sought to reaffirm Monday that it's still working closely with Russian space agency Rocosmos on the International Space Station, despite mounting geopolitical tensions.

TITLE: Why Ukraine war misinformation is so hard to police
SUMMARY: Russia's invasion of Ukraine is unfolding online like no war in history, providing a real-time stream of information on social platforms like Twitter, Facebook and TikTok. But with that unique view into the conflict comes a flood of misinformation that's especially hard to root out — effectively creating a digital fog of war.

TITLE: Intel will invest nearly $90 billion in Europe's chipmaking industry
SUMMARY: Intel plans to invest up to €80 billion ($89 billion) over the next decade to build up Europe's supply chain for semiconductor chips.

TITLE: VR headsets are headed to your car's backseat
SUMMARY: Forget the stereo. Your next car could come with a virtual reality entertainment system.

TITLE: Astra's stock takes wild ride after rocket launch
Instagram is rolling out new parental supervision tools
SUMMARY: Instagram is rolling out new tools that parents can use to help monitor and limit their kids' usage of the photo-sharing app, months after disclosures from a Facebook whistleblower raised concerns about the platform's impact on younger users.

TITLE: Facebook removes Zelensky deepfake
SUMMARY: Facebook's parent company, Meta, said Wednesday that it removed a deepfake video of Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelensky that purported to show him yielding to Russia.

TITLE: Facebook and YouTube say they removed Zelensky deepfake
SUMMARY: Facebook and YouTube said Wednesday that they removed uploads of a deepfake video of Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelensky that purported to show him yielding to Russia.

TITLE: Uber and Lyft are offering fuel surcharges and cash back offers for workers. Is it enough?
SUMMARY: For many gig workers, their vehicles are how they make a living. And as independent contractors, they're solely responsible for keeping them clean, running and full of gas. In recent weeks, the latter part has gotten much more burdensome.

TITLE: Samsung's latest budget 5G smartphone takes on the iPhone SE
SUMMARY: Barely a week after Apple unveiled its first budget 5G smartphone, Samsung announced a competing model that rivals it on price.

TITLE: SNL star Pete Davidson will no longer fly to space after launch postponed
SUMMARY: Saturday Night Live star Pete Davidson is not going to be on Blue Origin's next space flight after the company pushed back the launch date by six days.

TITLE: 'We come for our own': How Black volunteers rallied online to help African students in Ukraine
SUMMARY: After some of the hundreds of Black students stranded in the besieged city of Sumy, Ukraine, released desperate pleas for help on social media earlier this month, a grassroots group of volunteers sprang into action to help them safely evacuate the war zone.

TITLE: PayPal enables Ukrainian accounts to send and receive money
SUMMARY: PayPal said Thursday it is expanding its services for Ukrainian accounts and allowing them to send and receive money from friends and family.

TITLE: Social media platforms tread carefully when it comes to the Russian government
SUMMARY: As its troops have gotten bogged down in Ukraine, the Russian government has been fueling a conspiracy theory on social media about the purpose of US-funded biolabs in Ukraine.

TITLE: Match launches new dating app for single parents
SUMMARY: Match Group on Monday rolled out a new service called Stir that aims to remove some of the barriers around dating as a single parent.

TITLE: Why WhatsApp wants to convince Americans to stop sending text messages
SUMMARY: Since the start of this year, a series of advertisements have appeared on television screens and billboards across the United States, with ominous warnings to texters.

TITLE: Court halts construction of Amazon's Africa HQ on sacred land
SUMMARY: A South African judge has put the brakes on a $270 million real estate project that includes a regional headquarters for Amazon, saying that indigenous people who consider the land to be sacred must be consulted.

TITLE: SpaceX will now launch satellites for top space broadband competitor, OneWeb
SUMMARY: SpaceX has a new deal to launch internet-beaming satellites for its chief competitor in the satellite business — British company OneWeb.

TITLE: Apple services including App Store, Apple Music and iCloud hit by outage
SUMMARY: A number of Apple services were hit by an outage beginning around 1 p.m. ET on Monday.

TITLE: Blue Origin announces replacement for Pete Davidson on next space tourism mission
SUMMARY: Jeff Bezos' space company, Blue Origin, said it will replace Saturday Night Live star Pete Davidson with a long-time employee on the company's next supersonic jaunt to the edge of space.

TITLE: Google settles with 6 engineers who alleged they faced retaliation for organizing
SUMMARY: Google has reached a settlement with six engineers who alleged the company unlawfully retaliated against them over their workplace organizing efforts.

TITLE: Apple services including App Store, Apple Music and iCloud hit by brief outage
SUMMARY: A number of Apple services were hit by a short-lived outage for some users on Monday afternoon.

TITLE: Authentication services firm Okta says it is investigating report of breach
SUMMARY: Authentication services company Okta Inc said on Tuesday it is investigating a report of a digital breach after hackers posted screenshots of what they claimed were its internal company environment.

TITLE: Authentication firm Okta probes report of digital breach
SUMMARY: Authentication services provider Okta Inc is investigating a report of a digital breach, the company said on Tuesday, after hackers posted screenshots showing what they claimed was its internal company environment.

TITLE: Okta investigating reports of possible digital breach
SUMMARY: Okta is investigating reports of a possible digital breach, the software company said early Tuesday.

TITLE: The dark side of Discord for teens
SUMMARY: When a mother in Washington state learned her teenage daughter was on Discord, a popular social media platform, she felt reasonably comfortable with the idea of her using it to communicate with members of her high school marching band.

TITLE: 'It's absolutely critical.' Ex-Trump official backs Biden's computer chip push
SUMMARY: Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster is calling on Congress to swiftly fund investments in American computer chip manufacturing, a plan championed by the Biden administration to address global semiconductor shortages.

TITLE: DC sues Grubhub for allegedly employing deceptive practices
SUMMARY: The attorney general of Washington, D.C. announced Monday he is suing Grubhub, alleging that the company harmed consumers during the pandemic by charging hidden fees and by misleading consumers about them using so-called "dark patterns" — along with a battery of other claims.

TITLE: Okta concedes hundreds of clients could be affected by breach
SUMMARY: A January cybersecurity incident at popular identity authentication provider Okta may have affected hundreds of the firm's clients, Okta acknowledged late Tuesday amid an ongoing investigation of the breach.

TITLE: Instagram brings back option for reverse chronological feed
SUMMARY: Instagram is bringing back a version of its news feed that sorts posts in reverse chronological order rather than ranked according to the platform's algorithms. However, the company said it will leave its algorithm ranking method on by default.

TITLE: Microsoft confirms it was breached by hacker group
SUMMARY: Microsoft has confirmed it was breached by the hacker group Lapsus$, adding to the cyber gang's growing list of victims.

TITLE: US warns businesses to prepare for Russian cyberattacks. Here's how they can do that
SUMMARY: As Russia's war in Ukraine and its diplomatic conflict with the United States both continue to escalate, the warnings that Russian hackers could go after US businesses have gained new urgency.

TITLE: Mackenzie Scott has given $3.8 billion to 465 organizations since June
SUMMARY: Mackenzie Scott said Wednesday she has donated more than $3.8 billion to 465 organizations since June.

TITLE: Instacart wants to help grocers get in on the 15-minute delivery craze
SUMMARY: Instacart wants to help grocery stores get in on the ultra-fast delivery craze.

TITLE: Arizona is the first state to accept digital driver's licenses on iPhones
SUMMARY: iPhone owners with an Arizona driver's license or state ID can now upload either to their Apple Wallet, marking the first time a US state has supported digital versions of this type of identification in the app. But the uses remain very limited, for now.

TITLE: Tencent stock drops after its slowest quarter on record as China crackdown hits growth
SUMMARY: Tencent's stock suffered a sharp drop after the company reported its slowest-ever growth thanks to a bruising crackdown by China on the country's tech sector.

TITLE: Tencent stock tumbles after China crackdown hits growth
SUMMARY: Tencent's stock suffered a sharp drop after the company reported its slowest-ever growth due to a bruising crackdown by China on the country's tech sector.

TITLE: Stephen Wilhite, who created GIFs, dies at 74
SUMMARY: Wilhite, whose GIFs changed the way we communicate online, died March 14. His wife, Kathaleen, confirmed that Wilhite died from complications of Covid-19.
